title: Smaller banks hit harder by rate cuts
text:
Bendigo Bank’s decision to meet its bigger rivals has been viewed as an attempt to defend its market share at a cost to its bottom line, while Bank of Queensland maintains its rates are among the lowest in the market.

Bendigo Bank managing director Marnie Baker said the decision took into account the interests of “borrowers, depositors, small businesses, partners, shareholders and the broader community”.

Under the bank’s previous chief executive Mike Hirst, the lender articulated its mission to feed into the community’s prosperity rather than off it, paving the way for the larger cut and corresponding hit to the bottom line.

Morgan Stanley’s Mr Stadnik said the cuts would be felt immediately at Bendigo where mortgages are funded predominantly by deposits.

Bank of Queensland’s head of retail banking, Lyn McGrath, instead chose to frame the decision through the lens of depositors by saying it was “balancing the needs of our customers in a low interest rate environment”.

The impact of lower rates at Bank of Queensland is not as immediate due to its access to wholesale funding, however the decision to pass on just 10 basis points is expected to have a greater impact over time.

Bank of Queensland’s market share of mortgages has been flatlining despite its relatively aggressive pricing.

Queensland-based Heritage Bank passed on 15 basis points of the 25 to customers, using the opportunity to spruik a 25 basis point reduction in the rate charged on personal loans and credit cards.

JPMorgan’s Andrew Triggs said the banks' decisions to withhold large portions of the cut while non-bank lenders were able to pass on the full rate, would contribute to a loss of market share for all banks.

Mr Triggs said the gap between investor interest-only loans and others had narrowed considerably and was likely to continue, forcing banks to compete away a valuable source of profits.

With more cuts forecast and the number of deposit accounts inching towards zero interest rising, JPMorgan said that even less would be passed through to customers next time.

The big four banks passed on an average of 16 basis points to customers, and next time Mr Triggs has forecasted a pass through of only half the total.
description: Smaller banks will feel a disproportionate amount of pain from the latest rate cut and may even crimp competition.
